pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
Hi Ian!

Apologies, should have attached the models to give a visual comparison. I just took some screenshots and these are my results \(to be precise I had to merge the branch rmf to the one I opened the PR for in ign-common, since I need the custom\_path\_uri to be able to find the models in my simulation environment\).

First row is before the two PRs, second row is after, left is OGRE1 right is OGRE2.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/2349224540-transparent_assets.png)
‌

The OGRE1 is still not perfect because of the double sided rendering issue, however it is still “better” and from my understanding the two sided rendering is only necessary for fully planar surfaces, so changing the asset to have a thickness in the cage should fix it?

I’m not sure why our results are different, I’ll double check I don’t have any uncommitted change.

It’s not perfect but it’s still progress? Happy to iterate on this to make it better.
content.html:
Hi Ian!

Apologies, should have attached the models to give a visual comparison. I just took some screenshots and these are my results (to be precise I had to merge the branch rmf to the one I opened the PR for in ign-common, since I need the custom_path_uri to be able to find the models in my simulation environment).

First row is before the two PRs, second row is after, left is OGRE1 right is OGRE2.

‌

The OGRE1 is still not perfect because of the double sided rendering issue, however it is still “better” and from my understanding the two sided rendering is only necessary for fully planar surfaces, so changing the asset to have a thickness in the cage should fix it?

I’m not sure why our results are different, I’ll double check I don’t have any uncommitted change.

It’s not perfect but it’s still progress? Happy to iterate on this to make it better.

pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
ah nice, I was running outdated branch. I get what you have now.

for ogre1.x you can disable hardware culling to enable two sided lighting, i.e. `this->ogrePass->setCullingMode(Ogre::CULL_NONE);`

I’ll continue to test the changes tomorrow against other models to make sure we have not changed the behavior.
content.html:
ah nice, I was running outdated branch. I get what you have now.

for ogre1.x you can disable hardware culling to enable two sided lighting, i.e. this->ogrePass->setCullingMode(Ogre::CULL_NONE);

I’ll continue to test the changes tomorrow against other models to make sure we have not changed the behavior.

pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
I notice a change in behavior the new `SetTransparency` changes. I updated the `mesh_viewer` demo in the `transparent_materials_test` branch to test setting transparency to a regular mesh. Here’s before \(left\) and after \(right\) the change:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/1077075107-alpha_tex_comp.png)
‌

I’m looking into ways around it. I think we need an API to let users explicitly indicate that they want to use set transparency based on the texture’s alpha channel. Are you tied to using ign-rendering3? If not, we can the new API in `default`
content.html:
I notice a change in behavior the new SetTransparency changes. I updated the mesh_viewer demo in the transparent_materials_test branch to test setting transparency to a regular mesh. Here’s before (left) and after (right) the change:

‌

I’m looking into ways around it. I think we need an API to let users explicitly indicate that they want to use set transparency based on the texture’s alpha channel. Are you tied to using ign-rendering3? If not, we can the new API in default

pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
Thanks for the test case! I can reproduce it and will use it to come up with a better solution. I agree that the only way to do fix it properly is by breaking API, was hoping it wouldn’t be necessary but it seems it will be. I’ll retarget the PR to default.

I was thinking of either:

1. Changing the SetTransparency function to accept a boolean to enable / disable alpha based rendering.
2. Adding a function to enable and configure alpha rendering, maybe with a getter as well \(i.e. SetAlphaRendering / GetAlphaRendering\).
3. Changing the SetTexture function to accept a boolean for alpha based textures.

Personally I lean towards 2, with the addition of a parameter for the alpha test threshold, maybe with a sensible default so users don’t have to specify it. I’m guessing however, it wouldn’t make it to the ign-common/graphics Material API since it’s an OGRE specific setting so even making it a parameter wouldn’t probably be very useful.

Ideas?
content.html:
Thanks for the test case! I can reproduce it and will use it to come up with a better solution. I agree that the only way to do fix it properly is by breaking API, was hoping it wouldn’t be necessary but it seems it will be. I’ll retarget the PR to default.

I was thinking of either:

  1. Changing the SetTransparency function to accept a boolean to enable / disable alpha based rendering.
  2. Adding a function to enable and configure alpha rendering, maybe with a getter as well (i.e. SetAlphaRendering / GetAlphaRendering).
  3. Changing the SetTexture function to accept a boolean for alpha based textures.

Personally I lean towards 2, with the addition of a parameter for the alpha test threshold, maybe with a sensible default so users don’t have to specify it. I’m guessing however, it wouldn’t make it to the ign-common/graphics Material API since it’s an OGRE specific setting so even making it a parameter wouldn’t probably be very useful.

Ideas?

pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
I like option 2 too. How about something like `SetAlphaFromTexture(bool _enabled, double _alpha=0.5, bool _doubleSided=true)`? mainly to include the word `Texture` in the function name to make it evident that it’s coming from the texture.

the second param gives the alpha test threshold value. I think this is not specific to ogre. Looking around, I see similar idea can be found in [threejs](https://threejs.org/docs/#api/en/materials/Material.alphaTest) and [glTF2](https://github.com/KhronosGroup/glTF/tree/master/specification/2.0) \(called `alphaCutoff`\). The third argument could be called `culling` or `twoSided` to make sure two sides are visible.
content.html:
I like option 2 too. How about something like SetAlphaFromTexture(bool _enabled, double _alpha=0.5, bool _doubleSided=true)? mainly to include the word Texture in the function name to make it evident that it’s coming from the texture.

the second param gives the alpha test threshold value. I think this is not specific to ogre. Looking around, I see similar idea can be found in threejs and glTF2 (called alphaCutoff). The third argument could be called culling or twoSided to make sure two sides are visible.

pullrequest.title: Added basic support for alpha textures in ogre1 and ogre2

content.raw:
Progress! I retargeted the PR to default, created the new API function as you suggested and updated the ign-common PR in the process \(also targeting default since we are now breaking API\).

Current results below \(left is ogre1, right is ogre2\). As predicted a “proper” API fixes the weird rubber duck rendering issue you noticed before:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/3019182431-bitmap.png)
‌

You can probably notice how the ogre1 rendering looks a bit weird, and it’s the result of disabling hardware culling which makes the grid look a bit funky \(with hardware culling the hidden faces are never rendered but at least the front one look correct\), detail of the current glitch below:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/zq9ear/images/309815002-Selection_014.png)
‌

The issue seems to be due to the depth being incorrect, since “some triangles” of the back grid are rendered in front when they shouldn’t, but this is only a supposition.

‌
content.html:
Progress! I retargeted the PR to default, created the new API function as you suggested and updated the ign-common PR in the process (also targeting default since we are now breaking API).

Current results below (left is ogre1, right is ogre2). As predicted a “proper” API fixes the weird rubber duck rendering issue you noticed before:

‌

You can probably notice how the ogre1 rendering looks a bit weird, and it’s the result of disabling hardware culling which makes the grid look a bit funky (with hardware culling the hidden faces are never rendered but at least the front one look correct), detail of the current glitch below:

‌

The issue seems to be due to the depth being incorrect, since “some triangles” of the back grid are rendered in front when they shouldn’t, but this is only a supposition.

‌

content.raw:
looking good!

yeah I noticed the problem with ogre1 with culling disabled. In ogre2, the two sided lighting does extra things like flipping the normals of faces. If that’s not urgent for you, we can leave that for later.

looking good!

yeah I noticed the problem with ogre1 with culling disabled. In ogre2, the two sided lighting does extra things like flipping the normals of faces. If that’s not urgent for you, we can leave that for later.
